answer: FALSE.  This visual illusion may cause a pilot to believe that he is actually higher than he is, causing him to fly a low approach perhaps encountering obstacles or terrain. This is an excellent reason to employ any and all glide slope indications available, including but not limited to a PAPI, VASI, or, if equipped and capable, an instrument approach. And perhaps to avoid at night any runway without a visual glidepath indicator. (AIM 8-1-5)
question: When approaching at night a well-lit runway set in a dark area with little other surrounding lights or visible features, a pilot may be deceived into believing that he is lower than he actually is.  True or False?
